conclusion: Understanding the problem of an ideal gas going through a cyclic process to find work done.
PV diagram with volume on horizontal axis and pressure on vertical axis.
Process A to B: Pressure increases from 1 x 10^5 Pa to 4 x 10^5 Pa, volume constant at 2 liters.
Process B to C: Pressure decreases from 4 x 10^5 Pa to 1 x 10^5 Pa, volume increases from 2 liters to 5 liters.
Process C to A: Volume decreases from 5 liters to 2 liters, pressure constant at 1 x 10^5 Pa.
Cyclic process means changes in internal energy over the cycle are zero.
Net work done by gas is equal to area enclosed by cycle in PV diagram.
Work done from A to B is zero due to constant volume (isochoric process).
Calculate work done from B to C by integrating pressure with respect to volume.
Path from B to C is a straight line on PV diagram.
Assume linear path from B to C, calculate area under line as trapezoid.
Area of trapezoid calculated as (1/2) * (4 x 10^5 + 1 x 10^5) * 3 L.
Work from B to C = 2.5 x 10^5 Pa * 0.003 m³ = 750 J.
From C to A: Pressure constant at 1 x 10^5 Pa, volume decreases from 5 L to 2 L.
